required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Daratumumab in Treating Patients With Multiple Myeloma

lead_sponsor.agency: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

clinical_study.source: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

brief_summary.textblock: This phase II trial studies the side effects and how well daratumumab works in treating patients with multiple myeloma when the infusion is accelerated. Monoclonal antibodies, such as daratumumab, may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread.

detailed_description.textblock:
PRIMARY OBJECTIVES:
I. Determine the safety and tolerability of decreasing the infusion time of daratumumab in patients that have already received 2+ doses of daratumumab and are continuing on daratumumab.
II. Estimate the time savings versus (vs) predicted infusion time.
OUTLINE:
Patients receive daratumumab intravenously (IV) over 1.5 hours. Treatment continues in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.
After completion of study treatment, patients are followed up for 4 weeks.

primary_outcome.measure: Safety and tolerability of decreased infusion time for Daratumumab
primary_outcome.description: The start and stop times of daratumumab infusion will be tracked during infusion acceleration.

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of adverse events defined as grade 3-4 reactions assessed by Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE)
secondary_outcome.description: Analysis of AEs possibly, probably, or definitely related to protocol therapy will summarize infusion related grade 3-4 reactions.

IRR will be assessed with the first dose using the accelerated doing regimen. The incidence rate of IRR is defined and calculated as the number of patients with grade 3 IRR divided by the total number of patients who receive the accelerated dosing regimen.

arm_group.description: Patients receive daratumumab IV over 1.5 hours. Treatment continues in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients must have received >= 2 daratumumab infusions and be scheduled to receive another dose
- All races and ethnic groups are eligible for this study
- Ability to understand and the willingness to sign a written informed consent document
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any other medical condition, including mental illness or substance abuse, deemed by the principal investigator to likely interfere with a patient's ability to sign informed consent, cooperate and participate in the study, or interfere with the interpretation of the results
- Concurrent use of complementary or alternative medicines that in the opinion of the principal investigator would confound the interpretation of toxicities and/or antitumor activity of the study drug
- Prisoner

overall_official.affiliation: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

facility.name: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center
